instruction: I received a call claiming my National Insurance number has been suspended due to suspicious activity. They want me to press 1 to speak to an officer. What should I do?
output: Hang up immediately. This is a National Insurance scam. HMRC never calls about suspended National Insurance numbers, and they don't use automated messages asking you to press numbers. Report this scam to Action Fraud on 0300 123 2040.
source_document: Claude Generated - National Insurance Scams
source_url: Generated based on HMRC impersonation fraud

instruction: Someone is selling concert tickets on Twitter at face value, but they want payment via bank transfer and won't meet in person. Should I buy them?
output: No, this is likely a ticket fraud. Never buy tickets through bank transfers from people you haven't met, as these payments can't be reversed. Use official ticket exchanges, meet in person, or use payment methods with buyer protection like PayPal Goods & Services.
source_document: Claude Generated - Social Media Ticket Sales
source_url: Generated based on event ticket fraud

instruction: I'm selling my phone online and the buyer sent me a screenshot showing they've paid, but the money hasn't appeared in my account. They're asking me to post the phone. What should I do?
output: Don't send the phone. Screenshots can be easily faked. Wait until the money actually appears in your account and has cleared before sending any items. If they pressure you to send it early, it's definitely a scam.
source_document: Claude Generated - Payment Screenshot Scams
source_url: Generated based on online selling fraud

instruction: My elderly mother received a letter saying she's won £50,000 in a lottery she didn't enter, but needs to pay £200 in fees first. Is this legitimate?
output: No, this is a classic lottery scam. Legitimate lotteries never require upfront fees, and you can't win lotteries you haven't entered. These scams specifically target elderly people. Help your mother report this to Action Fraud and Trading Standards.
source_document: Claude Generated - Postal Lottery Scams
source_url: Generated based on elderly targeting fraud

instruction: I got a text saying my package delivery failed and I need to pay a £2 redelivery fee via a link. Should I pay it?
output: No, this is a delivery fee scam. Legitimate delivery companies don't ask for small redelivery fees via text links. The £2 charge is to steal your card details for much larger fraudulent transactions. Contact the delivery company directly if you're expecting a package.
source_document: Claude Generated - Delivery Fee Scams
source_url: Generated based on parcel delivery fraud

instruction: Someone on Facebook is offering iPhone 15s at half price, claiming they work for Apple and get employee discounts. They want payment via bank transfer. Is this legitimate?
output: No, this is a counterfeit goods scam. Apple employees don't sell devices this way, and genuine employee discounts aren't transferable. You'll either receive a fake phone or nothing at all. Never pay via bank transfer for discounted electronics from social media.
source_document: Claude Generated - Employee Discount Scams
source_url: Generated based on counterfeit electronics fraud

instruction: I received an email saying my Amazon Prime membership is about to expire and I need to update my payment method by clicking a link. Should I click it?
output: No, don't click the link. This is a phishing scam impersonating Amazon. Log into your Amazon account directly through their official website to check your Prime status. Amazon will never ask you to update payment details through email links.

source_url: Generated based on subscription phishing fraud

instruction: My teenager wants to buy limited edition trainers from someone on Instagram who claims they're sold out everywhere else. They're asking for payment upfront via cryptocurrency. Should I be concerned?
output: Yes, be very concerned. This is likely a counterfeit goods scam targeting young people's desire for exclusive items. Cryptocurrency payments can't be reversed, and genuine limited edition items aren't sold through random Instagram accounts. Stick to authorized retailers.

instruction: I'm looking for a rental property and found a perfect flat advertised online at below-market rent. The landlord wants first month's rent and deposit upfront before viewing. Is this normal?
output: No, this is a rental scam. Legitimate landlords allow viewings before requesting money, and deposits are protected by government schemes. Never pay upfront for properties you haven't seen in person. These scams use photos stolen from other property listings.
source_document: Claude Generated - Rental Property Scams
source_url: Generated based on housing fraud

instruction: Someone called claiming to be from my bank's fraud department saying there's been suspicious activity on my account. They asked me to verify my details to secure my account. Should I provide them?
output: Never give personal details to unexpected callers, even if they claim to be from your bank. This is a vishing scam. Hang up and call your bank directly using the number on your card or bank statements. Banks never ask for full details over the phone.
source_document: Claude Generated - Bank Fraud Department Scams
source_url: Generated based on banking impersonation fraud

instruction: I received a WhatsApp message from an unknown number offering me work-from-home data entry jobs paying £25 per hour. They want me to pay £50 for training materials. Is this legitimate?
output: No, this is an employment scam. Legitimate employers never ask candidates to pay for training materials or jobs. These scams take your money and provide no real work. Report the WhatsApp number and never pay upfront fees for job opportunities.
source_document: Claude Generated - Work From Home Job Scams
source_url: Generated based on employment fraud

instruction: My friend shared a post about a 'cash flipping' scheme where you send £100 and get £500 back within hours. They say they've tried it and it works. Should I participate?
output: No, cash flipping is always a scam, even if friends claim it works. Early participants might be paid with money from later victims to encourage more people to join, but eventually everyone loses their money. It's a type of Ponzi scheme that's illegal.
source_document: Claude Generated - Cash Flipping Scams
source_url: Generated based on social media financial fraud

instruction: I'm trying to book a holiday and found an amazing deal on a travel website I haven't heard of. They want full payment upfront and don't accept credit cards, only bank transfers. Should I book?
output: No, this is likely a travel scam. Legitimate travel companies accept credit cards which offer protection. Bank transfer-only policies and unfamiliar websites are red flags. Check if the company is ATOL or ABTA protected, and use payment methods that offer fraud protection.
source_document: Claude Generated - Travel Booking Scams
source_url: Generated based on holiday fraud

instruction: Someone contacted me about PPI compensation claiming I'm owed thousands of pounds, but they need me to pay an upfront fee for their service. Is this normal?
output: No, legitimate PPI claims companies work on a no-win, no-fee basis and take their percentage from successful claims. Never pay upfront fees for PPI claims. The official deadline for PPI claims passed in August 2019, so most current offers are scams.
source_document: Claude Generated - PPI Claims Scams
source_url: Generated based on financial compensation fraud

instruction: I received a call from someone claiming to be from Microsoft saying my computer license is about to expire and I need to renew it immediately over the phone. Is this genuine?
output: No, this is a tech support scam. Microsoft doesn't make unsolicited calls about license renewals, and Windows licenses don't expire requiring phone renewals. They're trying to trick you into paying for fake services or giving them remote access to your computer.

instruction: My grandmother received a call from someone claiming her grandchild is in jail abroad and needs money for bail. The caller knew family names but something seemed off. What should she do?
output: This is a grandparent scam. Criminals research families on social media to make calls seem believable. She should hang up immediately and contact the family member directly on their known number. Real legal troubles abroad would be handled through official channels, not phone calls demanding immediate money.
source_document: Claude Generated - Grandparent Scams
source_url: Generated based on family emergency fraud

instruction: I found a great job posting on Indeed, but when I applied, they immediately offered me the job without an interview and asked for my bank details for payroll setup. Is this normal?
output: No, this is an employment scam. Legitimate employers conduct interviews and don't offer jobs immediately without proper vetting. Asking for bank details upfront is a red flag - they might be planning identity theft or money laundering schemes using your account.

instruction: Someone on TikTok is promoting a cryptocurrency that they claim will make me rich quickly. They're offering a special discount if I buy through their link today. Should I invest?
output: No, this is likely a cryptocurrency scam. Legitimate investments don't promise guaranteed riches or use high-pressure tactics with time limits. Social media crypto promotions are often pump-and-dump schemes or complete frauds. Never invest based on social media recommendations.

instruction: I'm selling my car and a potential buyer says they'll send a courier to collect it and pay by cheque. They want me to deposit the cheque and release the car before it clears. Should I agree?
output: No, never release a vehicle before payment has fully cleared. This is a classic cheque fraud where the cheque will bounce after the car is gone. Wait for cheques to clear completely, or better yet, insist on cash or bank transfer when the buyer collects in person.

instruction: I received a text saying I've been exposed to COVID-19 and need to order a test kit immediately by clicking a link and paying £2 for delivery. Is this from the NHS?
output: No, the NHS never charges for COVID test kits or sends payment links via text. This is a health-related scam designed to steal your payment details. Official NHS testing is free and organized through official channels like the NHS website or 119 helpline.

instruction: Someone is offering to buy my designer watch through Instagram and wants to use an escrow service they suggest. They say it protects both buyers and sellers. Should I use their service?
output: No, be very cautious of buyer-suggested escrow services, as these are often fake websites designed to steal your item and money. Use well-known escrow services like those integrated into legitimate selling platforms, or meet in person for high-value transactions.

instruction: I received a call from someone claiming to be from HMRC saying I owe back taxes and will be arrested if I don't pay immediately via gift cards. Is this real?
output: No, this is a common HMRC impersonation scam. HMRC never demands immediate payment via gift cards or threatens arrest over the phone. They communicate through official letters and don't use gift cards for payments. Hang up and report this to Action Fraud.

output: Be very cautious. This sounds like a forex trading scam where early participants are encouraged to recruit friends. These advisors often use fake trading platforms showing fake profits. Many people lose their entire investment. Only use FCA-regulated financial advisors.

instruction: I'm booking a hotel and found a great deal on a website that looks professional, but they only accept wire transfers and don't provide a phone number. Should I book?
output: No, legitimate hotels and booking sites accept credit cards and provide contact information. Wire transfer-only payments and missing contact details are major red flags for fake booking sites. Use established booking platforms or contact hotels directly.

instruction: Someone claiming to be a police officer called saying they're investigating fraud and need me to move my money to a 'safe account' to protect it. Should I do this?
output: No, this is a courier fraud scam. Real police never ask you to move money to safe accounts or send officers to collect cash/cards. Police investigations don't require you to move your own money. Hang up and call 101 to verify if concerned.
